title: COVID-19 misinformation - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: COVID-19 misinformation of the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic) and [the origin](/wiki/Investigations_into_the_origin_of_COVID-19), prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of the disease has been [spread through social media](/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_social_media#Misinformation), text messaging, [[1]](#cite_note-FTTextMsg-1) and [mass media](/wiki/Media_coverage_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic). False information has been propagated by celebrities, politicians, and other prominent public figures. Many countries have passed laws against " [fake news](/wiki/Fake_news)", and thousands of people have been arrested for spreading COVID-19 misinformation. The spread of [COVID-19 misinformation by governments](/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_governments) has also been significant. [Commercial scams](/wiki/COVID-19_scams) have claimed to offer [at-home tests, supposed preventives, and "miracle" cures](/wiki/List_of_unproven_methods_against_COVID-19). [[2]](#cite_note-2) Several religious groups have claimed their faith will protect them from the virus. [[3]](#cite_note-3) Without evidence, some people have claimed the virus is a [bioweapon](/wiki/Bioweapon) accidentally or deliberately leaked from a laboratory, a [population control](/wiki/Human_population_planning) scheme, the result of a [spy operation](/wiki/Espionage), or the side effect of [5G](/wiki/5G) upgrades to cellular networks. [[4]](#cite_note-4) The [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) declared an "infodemic" of incorrect information about the virus that poses risks to global health. [[5]](#cite_note-Lowy-5) While belief in conspiracy theories is not a new phenomenon, in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, this can lead to adverse health effects. Cognitive biases, such as jumping to conclusions and [confirmation bias](/wiki/Confirmation_bias), may be linked to the occurrence of conspiracy beliefs. [[6]](#cite_note-6) Uncertainty among experts, when combined with a lack of understanding of the scientific process by laypeople, has likewise been a factor amplifying conspiracy theories about the COVID-19 pandemic. [[7]](#cite_note-7) In addition to health effects, harms resulting from the spread of misinformation and endorsement of conspiracy theories include increasing distrust of news organizations and medical authorities as well as divisiveness and political fragmentation. [[8]](#cite_note-8) Overview On 30 January 2020, the [BBC](/wiki/BBC) reported on the developing issue of conspiracy theories and bad health advice regarding COVID-19. Examples at the time included false health advice shared on social media and private chats, as well as conspiracy theories such as the outbreak being planned with the participation of the [Pirbright Institute](/wiki/Pirbright_Institute). [[9]](#cite_note-bbc_misinfo-9) [[10]](#cite_note-10) On 31 January, [The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian) listed seven instances of misinformation, adding the conspiracy theories about bioweapons and the link to [5G](/wiki/5G) technology, and including varied false health advice. [[11]](#cite_note-GUAR-11) In an attempt to speed up research sharing, many researchers have turned to [preprint](/wiki/Preprint) servers such as [arXiv](/wiki/ArXiv), [bioRxiv](/wiki/BioRxiv), [medRxiv](/wiki/MedRxiv), and [SSRN](/wiki/SSRN). Papers are uploaded to these servers without [peer review](/wiki/Peer_review) or any other editorial process that ensures research quality. Some of these papers have contributed to the spread of conspiracy theories. The most notable case was an unreviewed preprint paper uploaded to bioRxiv which claimed that the virus contained [HIV](/wiki/HIV) "insertions". Following objections, the paper was withdrawn. [[12]](#cite_note-12) [[13]](#cite_note-13) [[14]](#cite_note-14) Preprints about COVID-19 have been extensively shared online and some data suggest that they have been used by the media almost 10 times more than preprints on other topics. [[15]](#cite_note-BesançonPeiffer-Smadja2020-15) According to a study published by the [Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism](/wiki/Reuters_Institute_for_the_Study_of_Journalism), most misinformation related to COVID-19 involves "various forms of reconfiguration, where existing and often true information is spun, twisted, recontextualised, or reworked"; less misinformation "was completely fabricated". The study also found that "top-down misinformation from politicians, celebrities, and other prominent public figures", while accounting for a minority of the samples, captured a majority of the social media engagement. According to their classification, the largest category of misinformation (39%) was "misleading or false claims about the actions or policies of public authorities, including government and international bodies like the WHO or the UN". [[16]](#cite_note-reuters-institute-16) In addition to social media, television and radio have been perceived as sources of misinformation. In the early stages of the [COVID-19 pandemic in the United States](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States), [Fox News](/wiki/Fox_News) adopted an editorial line that the emergency response to the pandemic was politically motivated or otherwise unwarranted, [[17]](#cite_note-17) [[18]](#cite_note-18) and presenter [Sean Hannity](/wiki/Sean_Hannity) claimed on-air that the pandemic was a "hoax" (he later issued a denial). [[19]](#cite_note-19) When evaluated by media analysts, the effect of broadcast misinformation has been found to influence health outcomes in the population. In a [natural experiment](/wiki/Natural_experiment) (an experiment that takes place spontaneously, without human design or intervention), two similar television news programs that were shown on the Fox News network in February-March 2020 were compared. One program reported the effects of COVID-19 more seriously, while a second program downplayed the threat of COVID-19. The study found that audiences who were exposed to the news downplaying the threat were statistically more susceptible to increased COVID-19 infection rates and death. [[20]](#cite_note-Becker_Friedman_Institute-20) In August 2021, television broadcaster [Sky News Australia](/wiki/Sky_News_Australia) was criticised for posting videos on [YouTube](/wiki/YouTube) containing misleading medical claims about COVID-19. [[21]](#cite_note-21) [Conservative talk radio](/wiki/Conservative_talk_radio) in the US has also been perceived as a source of inaccurate or misleading commentary on COVID-19. In August and September 2021, several radio hosts who had discouraged COVID-19 vaccination, or expressed skepticism toward the COVID-19 vaccine, subsequently died from COVID-19 complications, among them [Dick Farrel](/wiki/Dick_Farrel), [Phil Valentine](/wiki/Phil_Valentine) and [Bob Enyart](/wiki/Bob_Enyart). [[22]](#cite_note-fahri-0901-22) [[23]](#cite_note-guardian-20210921-23) Misinformation on the subject of COVID-19 has been used by politicians, [interest groups](/wiki/Advocacy_group), and [state actors](/wiki/State_actor) in many countries for political purposes: to avoid responsibility, scapegoat other countries, and avoid criticism of their earlier decisions. Sometimes there is a financial motive as well. [[24]](#cite_note-24) [[25]](#cite_note-25) [[26]](#cite_note-buzzfeed_042220_origin-26) Multiple countries have been accused of spreading disinformation with state-backed operations in the social media in other countries to generate panic, sow distrust, and undermine democratic debate in other countries, or to promote their models of government. [[27]](#cite_note-rankin-27) [[28]](#cite_note-28) [[29]](#cite_note-iran_disinformation-29) [[30]](#cite_note-russian_disinformation-30) A [Cornell University](/wiki/Cornell_University) study of 38 million articles in English-language media around the world found that US President [Donald Trump](/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_the_United_States#Trump_administration) was the single largest driver of the misinformation. [[31]](#cite_note-Stolberg-31) [[32]](#cite_note-Economist_mistrust-32) Analysis published by [National Public Radio](/wiki/National_Public_Radio) in December 2021 found that as American counties showed higher vote shares for Trump in 2020, COVID-19 vaccination rates significantly decreased and death rates significantly increased. NPR attributed the findings to misinformation. [[33]](#cite_note-33) Virus origin The consensus among [virologists](/wiki/Virology) is that the most likely [origin of the SARS-CoV-2 virus](/wiki/Investigations_into_the_origin_of_COVID-19) to be natural [crossover from animals](/wiki/Zoonosis), having [spilled-over](/wiki/Spillover_infection) into the human population from bats, possibly through an intermediate animal host, although the exact transmission pathway has not been determined. [[34]](#cite_note-zoum-34) [[35]](#cite_note-NatureDivisive-35) [[36]](#cite_note-Hakim-36) [[37]](#cite_note-barh-37) [[38]](#cite_note-38) [Genomic](/wiki/Genome) evidence SARS-CoV-2 originated in [horseshoe bats](/wiki/Horseshoe_bat). [[35]](#cite_note-NatureDivisive-35) An alternative hypothesis under investigation, deemed unlikely by the majority of virologists given a lack of evidence, is that the virus may have accidentally escaped from the [Wuhan Institute of Virology](/wiki/Wuhan_Institute_of_Virology) in the course of standard research. [[36]](#cite_note-Hakim-36) [[39]](#cite_note-Frutos2021-39) A poll in July 2021 found that 52% of US adults believe COVID-19 escaped from a lab. [[40]](#cite_note-40) Unsubstantiated speculation and conspiracy theories related to this topic have gained popularity during the pandemic. Common conspiracy theories state that the virus was intentionally engineered, either as a bio-weapon or to profit from the sale of vaccines. According to the World Health Organization, genetic manipulation has been ruled out by genomic analysis. [[41]](#cite_note-41) [[36]](#cite_note-Hakim-36) [[42]](#cite_note-42) Many other origin stories have also been told, ranging from claims of secret plots by political opponents to a conspiracy theory about mobile phones. The [Pew Research Center](/wiki/Pew_Research_Center) found, for example, that in March 2020, one in three Americans believed the new coronavirus had been created in a lab; one in four thought it had been engineered intentionally. [[43]](#cite_note-AP20210215-43) The spread of these conspiracy theories is magnified through mutual distrust and animosity, as well as nationalism and the use of propaganda campaigns for political purposes. [[44]](#cite_note-44) The promotion of misinformation has been used by American far-right groups such as [QAnon](/wiki/QAnon), by rightwing outlets such as Fox News, by former US President Donald Trump and also other prominent Republicans to stoke anti-China sentiments, [[45]](#cite_note-Bannon-45) [[46]](#cite_note-TrumpMuddled-46) [[43]](#cite_note-AP20210215-43) and has led to increased anti-Asian activity on social media and in the real world. [[47]](#cite_note-47) This has also resulted in the bullying of scientists and public health officials, both online and in-person, [[54]](#cite_note-54) fueled by a highly political and oftentimes toxic debate on many issues. [[35]](#cite_note-NatureDivisive-35) [[55]](#cite_note-55) Such spread of misinformation and conspiracy theories has the potential to negatively affect public health and diminish trust in governments and medical professionals. [[56]](#cite_note-56) The resurgence of the lab leak and other theories was fueled in part by the publication, in May 2021, of early emails between National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) director [Anthony Fauci](/wiki/Anthony_Fauci) and scientists discussing the issue. Per the emails in question, Kristian Andersen (author of one study debunking genomic manipulation theories) had heavily considered the possibility, and emailed Fauci proposing possible mechanisms, before ruling out deliberate manipulation with deeper technical analysis. [[57]](#cite_note-GuardianNewStudies-57) [[58]](#cite_note-58) These emails were later misconstrued and used by critics to claim a conspiracy was occurring. [[59]](#cite_note-59) [[60]](#cite_note-60) The ensuing controversy became known as the " [Proximal Origin](/wiki/Proximal_Origin)". [[61]](#cite_note-61) [[62]](#cite_note-62) However, despite claims to the contrary in some US newspapers, no new evidence has surfaced to support any theory of a laboratory accident, and the majority of peer-reviewed research points to a natural origin. This parallels previous outbreaks of novel diseases, such as HIV, SARS and H1N1, which have also been the subject of allegations of laboratory origin. [[63]](#cite_note-LingForeign2021-63) [[64]](#cite_note-Gorski_revisit-64) Wuhan lab origin Bio-weapon One early source of the bio-weapon origin theory was former [Israeli secret service](/wiki/Israeli_secret_service) officer Dany Shoham, who gave an interview [The Washington Times](/wiki/The_Washington_Times) about the [biosafety level 4](/wiki/Biosafety_level_4) the [Wuhan Institute of [[65]](#cite_note-65) [[66]](#cite_note-Brewster-66) A scientist from Hong Kong, [Li-Meng Yan](/wiki/Li-Meng_Yan), fled China and released a [preprint](/wiki/Preprint) stating the virus was modified in a lab rather than having a natural evolution. In an ad hoc peer-review (as the paper was not submitted for traditional peer review as part of the standard scientific publishing process), her claims were labelled as misleading, unscientific, and an unethical promotion of "essentially conspiracy theories that are not founded in fact". [[67]](#cite_note-RRC190-67) Yan's paper was funded by the Rule of Law Society and the Rule of Law Foundation, two non-profits linked to [Steve Bannon](/wiki/Steve_Bannon), a former Trump strategist, and [Guo Wengui](/wiki/Guo_Wengui), an [expatriate](/wiki/Expatriate) Chinese billionaire. [[68]](#cite_note-68) This misinformation was further seized on by the American far-right, who have been known to promote [distrust of China](/wiki/Anti-Chinese_sentiment). In effect, this formed "a [[45]](#cite_note-Bannon-45) The idea of SARS-CoV-2 as a lab-engineered weapon is an element of the [Plandemic](/wiki/Plandemic) conspiracy theory, which proposes that it was deliberately released by China. [[64]](#cite_note-Gorski_revisit-64) [The Epoch Times](/wiki/The_Epoch_Times), an anti- [Chinese Communist Party](/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party) (CCP) newspaper affiliated with [Falun Gong](/wiki/Falun_Gong), has spread misinformation related to the COVID-19 pandemic in print and via social media including Facebook and YouTube. [[69]](#cite_note-:0-69) [[70]](#cite_note-:11-70) It has promoted anti-CCP rhetoric and [conspiracy theories](/wiki/Misinformation_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic#Misinformation_regarding_virus_origin) around the coronavirus outbreak, for example through an 8-page special edition called "How the Chinese Communist Party Endangered the World", which was distributed unsolicited in April 2020 to mail customers in areas of the United States, Canada, and Australia. [[71]](#cite_note-:10-71) [[72]](#cite_note-72) In the newspaper, the [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2) virus is known as the " [CCP](/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party) virus", and a commentary in the newspaper posed the question, "is the novel coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan an accident occasioned by weaponizing [[69]](#cite_note-:0-69) [[71]](#cite_note-:10-71) The paper's editorial board that COVID-19 patients cure themselves by "condemning the CCP" and "maybe a miracle will happen". [[73]](#cite_note-DB_Kitze-73) In response to the propagation of theories in the US of a Wuhan lab origin, the Chinese government promulgated the conspiracy theory that the virus was developed by the United States army at [Fort Detrick](/wiki/Fort_Detrick). [[74]](#cite_note-74) [[75]](#cite_note-:1-75) The conspiracy theory was also promoted by British MP [Andrew Bridgen](/wiki/Andrew_Bridgen) in March 2023. [[75]](#cite_note-:1-75) [[76]](#cite_note-Wheeler_Bridgen_2023March-76) In June 2023 the 'Sunday Times Insight team' produced an article in The Times saying they had spoken to US State Department investigators and that "One of the investigator sources said the secret military-funded experiments on the mine virus, RaTG13, began in 2016." Also that "the Wuhan scientists had inserted furin cleavage sites into viruses in 2019." [[77]](#cite_note-77) Gain-of-function research One idea used to support a laboratory origin invokes previous [gain-of-function research](/wiki/Gain-of-function_research) on coronaviruses. Virologist [Angela Rasmussen](/wiki/Angela_Rasmussen) argued that this is unlikely, due to the intense scrutiny and government oversight gain-of-function research is subject to, and that it is improbable that research on hard-to-obtain coronaviruses could occur under the radar. [[78]](#cite_note-78) The exact meaning of "gain of function" is disputed among experts. [[79]](#cite_note-Robertson_L-79) [[80]](#cite_note-Bryant-80) In May 2020, Fox News host [Tucker Carlson](/wiki/Tucker_Carlson) accused Anthony Fauci of having "funded the creation of COVID" through gain-of-function research at the Wuhan Institute of Virology (WIV). [[79]](#cite_note-Robertson_L-79) Citing an essay by science writer [Nicholas Wade](/wiki/Nicholas_Wade), Carlson alleged that Fauci had directed research to make bat viruses more infectious to humans. [[81]](#cite_note-Dapcevich_GOF-81) In a hearing the next day, US senator [Rand Paul](/wiki/Rand_Paul) alleged that the US National Institutes of Health (NIH) had been funding gain-of-function research in Wuhan, accusing researchers including epidemiologist [Ralph Baric](/wiki/Ralph_Baric) of creating "super-viruses". [[79]](#cite_note-Robertson_L-79) [[82]](#cite_note-Kessler_flap-82) Both Fauci and NIH Director [Francis Collins](/wiki/Francis_Collins) have denied that the US government supported such research. [[79]](#cite_note-Robertson_L-79) [[80]](#cite_note-Bryant-80) [[81]](#cite_note-Dapcevich_GOF-81) Baric likewise rejected Paul's allegations, saying that his lab's research into the potential in bat coronaviruses for cross-species transmission was not deemed gain-of-function by NIH or the University of North Carolina, where he works. [[82]](#cite_note-Kessler_flap-82) A 2017 study of [chimeric](/wiki/Chimeric_virus) bat coronaviruses at the WIV listed NIH as a sponsor; however, NIH funding was only related to sample collection. Based on this and other evidence, The Washington Post rated the claim of an NIH connection to gain-of-function research on coronaviruses as omissions and/or exaggerations". [[84]](#cite_note-84) Accidental release of collected sample Another theory suggests the virus arose in humans from an accidental infection of laboratory workers by a natural sample. [[39]](#cite_note-Frutos2021-39) Unfounded online speculation about this scenario has been widespread. [[36]](#cite_note-Hakim-36) In March 2021, an investigatory report released by the WHO described this scenario as "extremely unlikely" and not supported by any available evidence. [[85]](#cite_note-WHOJoint-85) The report acknowledged, however, that the possibility cannot be ruled out without further evidence. [[39]](#cite_note-Frutos2021-39) The investigation behind this report operated as a joint collaboration between Chinese and international scientists. [[86]](#cite_note-86) [[87]](#cite_note-87) At the release briefing for the report, WHO Director-General [Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus](/wiki/Tedros_Adhanom_Ghebreyesus) reiterated the report's calls for a deeper probe into all evaluated possibilities, including the laboratory origin scenario. [[88]](#cite_note-88) The study and report were criticised by heads of state from the US, the EU, and other WHO member countries for a lack of transparency and incomplete access to data. [[89]](#cite_note-89) [[90]](#cite_note-90) [[91]](#cite_note-91) Further investigations have also been requested by some scientists, including Anthony Fauci and signatories of a letter published in [Science](/wiki/Science_(journal)). [[92]](#cite_note-92) Since May 2021, some media organizations softened previous language that described the laboratory leak theory as "debunked" or a "conspiracy theory". [[93]](#cite_note-media_face_hard_questions-93) On the other hand, scientific opinion that an accidental leak is possible, but unlikely, has remained steady. [[94]](#cite_note-94) [[35]](#cite_note-NatureDivisive-35) A number of journalists and scientists have said that they dismissed or avoided discussing the lab leak theory during the first year of the pandemic as a result of perceived polarization resulting from Donald Trump's embrace of the theory. [[93]](#cite_note-media_face_hard_questions-93) [[46]](#cite_note-TrumpMuddled-46) [[95]](#cite_note-UnravelingOrigins-95) [[96]](#cite_note-96) Stolen from Canadian lab Some social media users have alleged that COVID-19 was stolen from a Canadian virus research lab by Chinese scientists. [Health Canada](/wiki/Health_Canada) and the [Public Health Agency of Canada](/wiki/Public_Health_Agency_of_Canada) said that this had "no factual basis". [[97]](#cite_note-nofact-97) The stories seem to have been derived from a July 2019 [CBC](/wiki/Canadian_Broadcasting_Corporation) news article stating that some Chinese researchers had their security access to the [National Microbiology Laboratory](/wiki/National_Microbiology_Laboratory) in Winnipeg, a [Level 4](/wiki/Biosafety_level#Biosafety_level_4) virology lab, after a [Royal Canadian Mounted Police](/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Mounted_Police) investigation. [[98]](#cite_note-escorted-98) [[99]](#cite_note-buzz_doxx-99) Canadian officials described this as an administrative matter and said there was no risk to the Canadian public. [[98]](#cite_note-escorted-98) Responding to the conspiracy theories, the CBC stated that its articles "never claimed the two scientists were spies, or that they brought any version of [a] coronavirus to the lab in Wuhan". While pathogen samples were transferred from the lab in Winnipeg to Beijing on 31 March 2019, neither of the samples contained a coronavirus. The Public Health Agency of Canada has stated that the shipment conformed to all federal policies, and that the researchers in question are still under investigation, and thus it cannot be confirmed nor denied that these two were responsible for sending the shipment. The location of the researchers under investigation by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police has also not been released. [[97]](#cite_note-nofact-97) [[100]](#cite_note-100) [[101]](#cite_note-20200128factcheck-101) In a January 2020 press conference, [NATO](/wiki/NATO) secretary-general [Jens Stoltenberg](/wiki/Jens_Stoltenberg), when asked about the case, stated that he could not comment specifically on it, but expressed concerns about "increased efforts by the nations to spy on NATO allies in different ways". [[102]](#cite_note-Shoham-102) Accusations by China According to [The Economist](/wiki/The_Economist), conspiracy theories exist on China's internet about COVID-19 being created by the CIA in order to "keep China down". [[103]](#cite_note-20200208economist-103) According to an investigation by [ProPublica](/wiki/ProPublica), such conspiracy theories and disinformation have been propagated under the direction of [China News Service](/wiki/China_News_Service), the country's second largest government-owned media outlet by [United Work Department](/wiki/United_Front_Work_Department). [[104]](#cite_note-20200326propublica-104) [Global Times](/wiki/Global_Times) and [Xinhua News Agency](/wiki/Xinhua_News_Agency) have similarly propagating disinformation related to COVID-19's origins. [[105]](#cite_note-Dodds-105) [NBC News](/wiki/NBC_News) however has noted that there have also been debunking efforts of US-related conspiracy theories posted online, with a WeChat search of "Coronavirus [disease 2019] is from the U.S." reported to mostly yield articles explaining why such claims are unreasonable. [[106]](#cite_note-nbcnews1151291-106) [[a]](#cite_note-119) On 12 March 2020, two spokesmen for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, [Zhao Lijian](/wiki/Zhao_Lijian) and [Geng Shuang](/wiki/Geng_Shuang), alleged at a press conference that Western powers may have "bio-engineered" COVID-19. They were alluding that the US Army created and spread COVID-19, allegedly during the [2019 Military World Games in Wuhan](/wiki/2019_Military_World_Games), where numerous cases of [influenza-like illness](/wiki/Influenza-like_illness) were reported. [[119]](#cite_note-CNN_2020-03-18-120) [[120]](#cite_note-121) A member of the U.S. military athletics delegation based at Fort Belvoir, who competed in the [50mi Road Race](/wiki/Road_bicycle_racing) at the Wuhan games, became the subject of online targeting by netizens accusing her of being "patient zero" of the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan, and was later interviewed by CNN, to clear her name from the "false accusations in starting the pandemic". [[121]](#cite_note-122) In January 2021, [Hua Chunying](/wiki/Hua_Chunying) renewed the conspiracy theory from Zhao Lijian and Geng Shuang that the SARS-CoV-2 virus originating in the United States at the [U.S. biological weapons lab](/wiki/United_States_biological_weapons_program) [Fort Detrick](/wiki/Fort_Detrick). This conspiracy theory quickly went trending on the Chinese social media platform Weibo, and Hua Chunying continued to cite evidence on Twitter, while asking the government of the United States to open up Fort Detrick for further investigation to determine if it is the source of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. [[122]](#cite_note-123) [[123]](#cite_note-Guardian_Davidson-124) In August 2021, a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman repeatedly used an official podium to elevate the Fort Detrick's origin unproven idea. [[124]](#cite_note-125) According to a report from [Foreign Policy](/wiki/Foreign_Policy), Chinese diplomats and government officials in concert with China's propaganda apparatus and covert networks of online agitators and influencers have responded, focused on repeating [Zhao Lijian](/wiki/Zhao_Lijian)'s allegation relating to Fort Detrick in Maryland, and the "over 200 U.S. biolabs" around the world. [[125]](#cite_note-126) Accusations by Russia On 22 February 2020, US officials alleged that Russia is behind an ongoing disinformation campaign, using thousands of social media accounts on Twitter, Facebook and [CIA](/wiki/CIA) and the US is waging economic war on China using the virus. [[126]](#cite_note-guardian-rus-disinfo-127) [[127]](#cite_note-scmp3051939-128) [[128]](#cite_note-yahoo171730161-129) [[b]](#cite_note-135) In March 2022, amid the [2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine), the Russian Defense Ministry stated that US President [Joe Biden](/wiki/Joe_Biden)'s son, [Hunter Biden](/wiki/Hunter_Biden), as well as billionaire [George Soros](/wiki/George_Soros), were closely tied to Ukrainian biolabs. American right-wing media personalities, such as [Tucker Carlson](/wiki/Tucker_Carlson), highlighted the story, while Chinese Communist Party-owned tabloid Global Times further stated that the labs had been studying bat coronaviruses, which spread widely on the Chinese internet for insinuating that the United States had created SARS-CoV-19 in Ukrainian laboratories. [[134]](#cite_note-136) [[135]](#cite_note-137) Accusations by other countries According to Washington, DC-based nonprofit [Middle East Media Research Institute](/wiki/Middle_East_Media_Research_Institute), numerous writers in the Arabic press have promoted the conspiracy theory that COVID-19, as well as SARS and the swine flu virus, were deliberately created and spread to sell vaccines against these diseases, and it is "part of an economic and psychological war waged by the U.S. against China with the aim of weakening it and presenting it as a backward country and a source of diseases". [[136]](#cite_note-MEMRI-arab-disinfo-138) [[c]](#cite_note-139) Accusations in Turkey of Americans creating the virus as a weapon have been reported, [[137]](#cite_note-140) [[138]](#cite_note-141) and a [YouGov](/wiki/YouGov) poll from August 2020 found that 37% of Turkish respondents believed the US government was responsible for creating and spreading the virus. [[139]](#cite_note-142) An Iranian cleric in [Qom](/wiki/Qom) said [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump) targeted the city with and honor". [[140]](#cite_note-radiofarda30449087-143) [Reza Malekzadeh](/wiki/Reza_Malekzadeh), Iran's deputy health minister and former Minister of Health, rejected claims that the virus was a biological weapon, pointing out that the US would be suffering heavily from it. He said Iran was hard-hit because its close ties to China and reluctance to cut air ties introduced the virus, and because early cases had been mistaken for influenza. [[141]](#cite_note-20200314alarabiyaA-144) [[d]](#cite_note-153) In Iraq, pro-Iranian social media users waged a Twitter campaign during Trump's Presidency to end U.S. presence in the country by blaming it for the virus. The campaign centered around hashtags such as #Bases_of_the_American_pandemic and #Coronavirus_is_Trump's_weapon. A March 2020 survey by [USCENTCOM](/wiki/USCENTCOM) found that 67% of Iraqi respondents believed a foreign force was behind COVID-19, with 72% of them naming the USA as that force. [[150]](#cite_note-154) Theories blaming the USA have also circulated in the Philippines, [[e]](#cite_note-157) Venezuela [[f]](#cite_note-160) and Pakistan. [[155]](#cite_note-161) An October 2020 [Globsec](/wiki/Globsec) poll of [Eastern European](/wiki/Eastern_Europe) countries found that 38% of respondents in Montenegro and Serbia, 37% of those in North Macedonia, and 33% in Bulgaria believed the USA deliberately created COVID-19.
